metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Ruptured popliteal artery aneurysm complicated with ARDS secondary to SARS- CoV-2 infection Ruptured popliteal artery aneurysm complicated with ARDS 1 secondary to SARS-CoV-2 infection. 2 3 Declaration of conflicting interests

abstract.text: We herein report a rare case of the ruptured popliteal artery aneurysm in an 89 year old male, 35 whose recovery after surgical treatment was complicated with acute respiratory distress syndrome 36

body_text.text: Popliteal artery aneurysms (PAAs) account for more than 80% of all peripheral arterial aneurysms 42 with prevalence in men (1, 2) . PAA is the most often treated extracranial aneurysm (apart from the 43 aorta), and thus constitutes an important clinical condition (3,4). The most common complications 44 encompass distal embolization and thrombosis, leading to acute or chronic limb-threatening 45 ischaemia. Rupture of PAA is rare and accounts for between 2% to 5% of cases in large series (5). It 46 mainly occurs in large or septic aneurysms, as well as, many years after successful surgical exclusion (6). 48
Herein, we present a case of ruptured PAA leading to acute limb ischaemia in a patient who 49 developed rapidly progressing chest infection secondary to SARS-CoV-2 infection. 50

Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a respiratory disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. Clinical 51 manifestation of COVID-19 varies from asymptomatic, acute respiratory distress to pneumonia of 52 varying degrees of severity (7). It primarily spreads through respiratory tract by droplets, respiratory secretions, and direct contact. COVID-19 is deemed to be highly contagious during its latency period 54 and is highly transmittable in humans. Its median incubation period has been estimated to be 3 days 55 but can be as long as 24 days (7,8). 56

Case report cough. SARS-CoV-2 was suspected and later confirmed on throat swabs. Repeated blood results 96 revealed WBC count of 5.2 10*9/l with lymphocyte count of 0.3 10*9/l. In view of his medical 97 background, a multidisciplinary team decision (including his daughter and geriatrician) was made 98 that ceiling of care would be limited to level I ward based care. His condition started deteriorating 99 rapidly and he, sadly, passed away on day six after his amputation due to acute respiratory distress 100 syndrome (ARDS), which was diagnosed in accordance to berlin criteria, inflicted with SARS-CoV-2 morbidity and mortality. A primary amputation has been described as the last resort in cases where 105 arterial reconstructive surgery is not possible or considered high risk, and was reported in three out 106 of 48 cases (6.25%) in a recent systematic review of the literature (10). 107

In the presented case, the endovascular approach was not appropriate due to occluded runoff 108 vessels and unsuitable anatomy. The only remaining options for invasive intervention were open 109 repair with a bypass or a major amputation. Due to his comorbidities, he was at high risk of mortality 110 from prolonged surgery, so (as he was keen on intervention) the decision was made to proceed with 111 the above knee amputation. 112

Emerging evidence shows that advanced age, underlying comorbidities, such as cardiovascular 113 disease, diabetes mellitus, cancer and COPD, are independent risk factors of adverse outcomes in 114 SARS-CoV-2 infections (11,12). The three primary symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, cough, and 115

shortness of breath. Symptoms may appear within a varying timeframe after exposure (from 2 days 116 to 14 days). The most common COVID-19 related complications encompass ARDS (29%), viremia 117 (15%), acute cardiac injury determined by elevated high sensitivity troponin (12%) and secondary 118 infection (10%) (11). Moreover, emerging evidence suggests a correlation between cardiac events, 119 such as myocardial infarction, myocarditis and heart failure, and infection with SARS-CoV-2, resulting 120 in adverse outcomes (13).

FIGREF0.text: year -old male was admitted under the medical team following a head injury he sustained 58 as a result of a fall at home. On admission he complained of right knee swelling and difficulty in 59 bearing weight on that limb. His past medical history included severe chronic obstructive pulmonary 60 disease (COPD), chronic kidney disease with an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 32 ml/min, 61 transient ischaemic stroke, ischemic heart disease and atrial fibrillation. His ambulation was limited 62 by shortness of breath and his mobility was mainly limited to domiciliary activity.63 On the second day of his admission, a postural hypotension and concomitant drop in the 64 haemoglobin level were recognised. A computed tomography (CT) of his chest, abdomen and pelvis 65 was performed to identify a potential source of blood loss. The CT scan demonstrated haematoma in 66 the medial compartment of the right thigh. Subsequently, an arterial phase CT scan of the lower 67 limbs identified a 6.3 cm ruptured PAA (P1 segment of the right popliteal artery) with distal 68 thrombosis and with a significant haematoma in the medial and posterior thigh compartments 69 (Figure 1). He was also diagnosed with an incidental 47 mm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. 70 The patient was promptly referred to the vascular surgeons. 71 On assessment by the vascular surgeons, the patient appeared frail, with shortness of breath at rest 72 (saturation on room air was 95%), complaining of rest pain in the right foot and in the thigh. The 73 right foot was viable though with reduced sensation and motor function (IIB Rutherford 74 classification). He also had extensive swelling of the thigh and bruising involving the medial and 75 posterior aspect of the right thigh. A bed side arterial duplex scan confirmed absent flow distal to 76 the ruptured PAA. 77 than palliation) and, after a detailed discussion with him and his family (based on his extensive 80 medical background and frailty), an above knee amputation was carried out under spinal 81 anaesthesia. 82 He suffered a NSTEMI (non-ST elevation myocardial infarction) the following day, for which he was 83 treated in accordance with the local Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) protocol. ECG showed T wave 84 inversion in V4 to V6 leads and the high sensitivity troponin I level was 143 ng/l. Blood results also 85 revealed a white blood cell count (WBC) of 7.3 10*9/l, with lymphocyte count of 0.9 10*9/l and 86 normal neutrophil count. On the third day after his amputation, he developed signs of chest 87 infection including increased respiratory rate to 29 per minute and mild drop in oxygen saturation to 88 95%. Clinical examination revealed bibasal crepitations and chest radiography demonstrated fluid 89 overload and basal atelectasis. Repeated bloods displayed WBC of 6.7, with lymphocyte count of 0.6 90 and normal neutrophil count. Oxygen therapy was initiated along with Piperacillin/Tazobactam in 91 accordance with our local infectious disease guidelines and intravenous diuretic (Furosemide). His 92 condition started improving -respiratory rate returned to 18 per minute and his oxygen saturation 93 increased to 98% on room air after 24 hours of treatment. 94 On day five, he unexpectedly developed high temperature of 38.5 degrees of Celsius and new dry 95
